title: Isaiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 42 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 42.

questions.question: Who is described as God's servant in Isaiah 42:1?
options: Mine elect, in whom my soul delighteth
questions.correctAnswer: Mine elect, in whom my soul delighteth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:1 states, 'Behold my servant, whom I uphold; mine elect, in whom my soul delighteth,' identifying God's servant as His elect in whom He delights.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42:2, what will the servant not do?
options: Cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street
questions.correctAnswer: Cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:2 says the servant 'shall not cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street,' describing his gentle nature.

questions.question: What will the servant not break according to Isaiah 42:3?
questions.correctAnswer: A bruised reed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:3 states, 'A bruised reed shall he not break,' highlighting the servant’s compassion toward the weak.

questions.question: What will the servant not fail nor be discouraged until he sets judgment in the earth? (Isaiah 42:4)
options: He shall not fail nor be discouraged
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not fail nor be discouraged
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:4 explains that the servant 'shall not fail nor be discouraged, till he have set judgment in the earth.'

questions.question: Who created the heavens and stretched them out according to Isaiah 42:5?
questions.correctAnswer: God the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:5 states, 'Thus saith God the LORD, he that created the heavens, and stretched them out;' identifying God as creator.

questions.question: What has the LORD called the servant to be according to Isaiah 42:6?
options: A covenant of the people, for a light of the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant of the people, for a light of the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:6 says, 'I the LORD have called thee... and give thee for a covenant of the people, for a light of the Gentiles;' describing the servant’s mission.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42:7, what will the servant open?
questions.correctAnswer: The blind eyes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:7 states, 'To open the blind eyes, to bring out the prisoners from the prison...' indicating the servant’s role in liberation and enlightenment.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 42:8 says God will give His glory to graven images.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:8 clearly states, 'my glory will I not give to another, neither my praise to graven images,' denying giving glory to idols.

questions.question: What are we instructed to sing in Isaiah 42:10?
options: A new song unto the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: A new song unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:10 commands, 'Sing unto the LORD a new song,' encouraging fresh praise for God.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42:13, how will the LORD go forth?
options: As a mighty man, stirring up jealousy like a man of war
As a king on a throne
questions.correctAnswer: As a mighty man, stirring up jealousy like a man of war
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:13 describes the LORD going forth 'as a mighty man, he shall stir up jealousy like a man of war,' emphasizing His power.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 42:14 indicates that God has been silent for a long time but will now cry like a travailing woman.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:14 says, 'I have long time holden my peace;... now will I cry like a travailing woman,' showing God’s change from silence to action.

questions.question: What will God do to the mountains and hills according to Isaiah 42:15?
questions.correctAnswer: Make waste mountains and hills
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:15 states, 'I will make waste mountains and hills,' indicating destruction or desolation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'And I will bring the blind by a way that they knew not; I will lead them in paths that they have not known: I will make darkness ______ before them, and crooked things straight.' (Isaiah 42:16)
questions.correctAnswer: light
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:16 says, 'I will make darkness light before them,' showing God’s power to transform and guide.

questions.question: Who are described as being turned back and ashamed for trusting in graven images in Isaiah 42:17?
options: Those who trust in graven images
questions.correctAnswer: Those who trust in graven images
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:17 states, 'They shall be turned back, they shall be greatly ashamed, that trust in graven images,' referring to idolaters.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 42:18 calls on the deaf and blind to hear and see.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:18 says, 'Hear, ye deaf; and look, ye blind, that ye may see,' urging spiritual awareness.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 42 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling discouraged in their service for God. Based on Isaiah 42, what biblical truth could you share about perseverance and encouragement?
options: He shall not fail nor be discouraged, till he have set judgment in the earth
He will cry loudly and be heard in the streets
He will break the bruised reed and quench the smoking flax
He will abandon those who stray from the path
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not fail nor be discouraged, till he have set judgment in the earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:4 teaches that the servant will not fail or be discouraged until justice is established, providing encouragement to persevere. This is supported by verses 1, 3, and 16 that emphasize the servant's steadfastness and gentle care.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 42 teach us about humility in leadership and witness?
options: He shall not cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street
He shall boast loudly of his accomplishments
He will demand respect through force
He will be loud and aggressive in public
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:2 highlights the humility of the servant who does not raise his voice or shout, emphasizing quiet and gentle leadership. This is consistent with verses 3 and 16 which further describe gentle care and guidance.

questions.question: A believer struggling with self-doubt asks about God’s support. What assurance from Isaiah 42 would you share about God’s help?
options: I the LORD have called thee in righteousness, and will hold thine hand, and will keep thee
You must rely only on your strength
God will leave you to face trials alone
You must prove yourself worthy without help
questions.correctAnswer: I the LORD have called thee in righteousness, and will hold thine hand, and will keep thee
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:6 assures believers that God calls in righteousness and promises to hold and keep them, reinforcing trust and dependence on God. Verses 5 and 16 also affirm God’s sustaining power and guidance.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 42 encourage believers in evangelism and sharing the Gospel?
options: I will give thee for a covenant of the people, for a light of the Gentiles
Evangelism is optional and not important
Only preach to people like you
questions.correctAnswer: I will give thee for a covenant of the people, for a light of the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:6 reveals the servant’s role as a covenant and light to the Gentiles, encouraging believers to be witnesses and share God’s truth broadly. Verses 1, 7, and 10 also support this mission of outreach.

questions.question: When dealing with temptation and trials, what model does Isaiah 42 provide for maintaining faith?
options: He shall not fail nor be discouraged until judgment is set in the earth
Ignore God and rely on your own wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not fail nor be discouraged until judgment is set in the earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:4 teaches perseverance in faith despite challenges, promising the servant will not fail or become discouraged. This is echoed in verses 1, 13, and 16, which show God’s power and steadfastness in trials.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 42 instruct believers about compassion and care for the weak?
options: A bruised reed shall he not break, and the smoking flax shall he not quench
Only care for the strong and successful
questions.correctAnswer: A bruised reed shall he not break, and the smoking flax shall he not quench
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:3 models the servant’s gentle compassion, protecting and nurturing the weak and vulnerable. This reflects God’s character and calls believers to show similar compassion, supported by verses 7 and 16.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 42 teach about the importance of obedience and faithfulness to God’s law?
options: The LORD is well pleased for his righteousness' sake; he will magnify the law, and make it honourable
The law is optional and can be ignored
Obedience is less important than personal freedom
Only some laws need to be followed
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is well pleased for his righteousness' sake; he will magnify the law, and make it honourable
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:21 emphasizes God's pleasure in righteousness and His intention to honor His law, teaching believers to uphold obedience and faithfulness. Verses 24 and 25 warn of consequences for disobedience, reinforcing this principle.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to forgive others. What biblical truth about God’s glory and praise in Isaiah 42 could encourage humility and love?
options: I am the LORD: that is my name: and my glory will I not give to another
Seek praise from men rather than God
questions.correctAnswer: I am the LORD: that is my name: and my glory will I not give to another
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:8 declares God’s exclusive glory and calls believers to humbly give praise to Him alone, encouraging humility and reverence rather than pride or resentment. This supports loving others as God is glorified by humility.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 42 guide believers in trusting God’s guidance during uncertain times?
options: I will bring the blind by a way that they knew not; I will lead them in paths that they have not known
Ignore God’s direction and trust your own instinct
Avoid change and stay where you are comfortable
questions.correctAnswer: I will bring the blind by a way that they knew not; I will lead them in paths that they have not known
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:16 teaches that God leads His people through unfamiliar ways, providing light in darkness and straightening crooked paths, encouraging believers to trust His guidance. Verses 6 and 7 also affirm His calling and sustaining hand.

questions.question: A fellow believer is frustrated with the lack of visible results in their work for the Lord. What truth from Isaiah 42 would you share about God’s timing and faithfulness?
options: Behold, the former things are come to pass, and new things do I declare: before they spring forth I tell you of them
Give up if you don’t see immediate results
God is unaware of your efforts
Success depends on your own strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: Behold, the former things are come to pass, and new things do I declare: before they spring forth I tell you of them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:9 reveals God’s sovereign control over past and future events, assuring believers of His faithfulness and perfect timing, encouraging trust and patience. This is supported by verses 4 and 13 about God’s ultimate victory.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 42, God promises to forsake those who follow Him through trials.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:16 explicitly states that God will not forsake those He leads through difficult paths, assuring believers of His faithful presence during trials. Verses 6 and 7 also emphasize God’s sustaining hand and calling.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 42 describes the LORD as a warrior who will prevail against His enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:13 depicts the LORD going forth as a mighty man and prevailing against His enemies, portraying God’s power and victory in spiritual battle. This encourages believers to trust in God’s strength.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 42:7 says the servant is called to open the blind eyes, to bring out the prisoners from the prison, and them that sit in darkness out of the ____ house.
questions.correctAnswer: prison
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:7 uses the image of freeing prisoners and opening blind eyes, emphasizing the servant’s role in liberation from 'prison house,' symbolizing spiritual freedom. This aligns with verses 16 and 18 about guiding and enabling sight.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 42 instruct believers about honesty and integrity in daily life?
options: The LORD is well pleased for his righteousness' sake; he will magnify the law, and make it honourable
Dishonesty is acceptable if it benefits you
Integrity can be sacrificed for success
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is well pleased for his righteousness' sake; he will magnify the law, and make it honourable
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:21 teaches that God's righteousness and law are to be honored, calling believers to live with honesty and integrity. Verses 22-25 warn that ignoring God’s ways leads to ruin, reinforcing this teaching.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42, how should believers respond to idols or graven images?
options: Do not give God's glory or praise to graven images
Idols are acceptable replacements for God
questions.correctAnswer: Do not give God's glory or praise to graven images
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:8 warns that God will not give His glory or praise to graven images, instructing believers to worship Him alone and reject idolatry. Verses 17 and 18 further expose the folly of trusting idols.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 42.

questions.question: In Isaiah 42:1, the phrase 'my servant' most likely refers to which Messianic figure known from the New Testament?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:1 describes 'my servant' as the one God upholds and delights in, which the New Testament identifies as Jesus Christ (cf. Matthew 12:18).

questions.question: What is the significance of the imagery 'A bruised reed shall he not break, and the smoking flax shall he not quench' in Isaiah 42:3?
options: It symbolizes gentleness and care for the weak
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes gentleness and care for the weak
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:3 uses this metaphor to convey the servant's tender and compassionate nature, showing mercy rather than harsh judgment.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42:6, the servant is given for a covenant of the people and a light to whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:6 explicitly states the servant will be 'a light of the Gentiles,' indicating a mission beyond Israel.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominent in Isaiah 42:9 where God declares 'former things are come to pass, and new things do I declare'?
questions.correctAnswer: Foreshadowing
questions.explanation: The declaration in Isaiah 42:9 foreshadows future divine acts, showing God's sovereignty over history and revelation.

questions.question: Isaiah 42:13 describes the LORD going forth as a mighty man who stirs up jealousy. What Old Testament motif does this evoke?
questions.correctAnswer: The warrior-king motif
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:13 uses imagery of a warrior to depict God's power and victory over enemies, a common Old Testament theme for divine kingship.

questions.question: In Isaiah 42:16, the phrase 'I will make darkness light before them, and crooked things straight' is an example of what kind of parallelism?
questions.correctAnswer: Antithetic parallelism
questions.explanation: The verse contrasts darkness with light and crookedness with straightness, showing opposite ideas in parallel lines characteristic of antithetic parallelism.

questions.question: The phrase 'I am the LORD: that is my name' in Isaiah 42:8 emphasizes what theological concept?
options: The need for worship in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: God's unique identity and sovereignty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:8 stresses that the LORD alone is God and will not share His glory with idols, affirming divine exclusivity and sovereignty.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly echoes the mission described in Isaiah 42:7 to 'open the blind eyes' and 'bring out the prisoners from the prison'?
questions.explanation: Jesus quotes Isaiah 61 in Luke 4:18-19, which includes similar themes of liberation and healing, aligning with Isaiah 42:7's mission.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 42:2 describes the servant as one who will cry out loudly in the streets to proclaim judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:2 explicitly states the servant 'shall not cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street,' indicating quiet and gentle proclamation.

questions.question: The repeated references to 'blind' and 'deaf' in Isaiah 42:18-20 primarily serve to highlight what theme?
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual blindness and deafness
questions.explanation: These verses use blindness and deafness metaphorically to describe Israel's spiritual insensitivity to God’s revelation.

questions.question: In Isaiah 42:22, the people are described as 'robbed and spoiled' and 'snared in holes.' What historical context does this imagery likely reflect?
questions.correctAnswer: The Assyrian exile and oppression
questions.explanation: The imagery in Isaiah 42:22 reflects Israel’s experience of invasion and captivity, often associated with Assyrian dominance in the 8th century BCE.

questions.question: How does the servant's role in Isaiah 42:4, 'He shall not fail nor be discouraged, till he have set judgment in the earth,' relate to the theme of covenant fulfillment?
options: It emphasizes the servant's perseverance in establishing God's justice
It suggests the servant will abandon the covenant
It predicts immediate judgment without patience
It focuses on Israel’s military success
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the servant's perseverance in establishing God's justice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:4 highlights the servant’s unwavering commitment to fulfill God’s covenant promises of justice on earth.

questions.question: Isaiah 42:5 attributes creation to the LORD. How does this verse enhance the understanding of God's authority in the chapter?
options: It establishes God as the sovereign Creator who empowers the servant
It limits God's role to the heavens only
It suggests multiple gods created the earth
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes God as the sovereign Creator who empowers the servant
questions.explanation: By naming God as Creator of heavens and earth in Isaiah 42:5, the text asserts His supreme authority behind the servant’s mission.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42:25, what is the consequence of Israel's disobedience to God's law?
options: God pours out the fury of His anger upon them
They become kings of the nations
questions.correctAnswer: God pours out the fury of His anger upon them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:25 explains that because Israel did not obey, God’s wrath was poured out as a form of judgment.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'new song' mentioned in Isaiah 42:10, and how does it connect to the chapter's overall message?
options: To praise God's salvation and universal reign
To mourn the destruction of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: To praise God's salvation and universal reign
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:10 calls for a new song of praise from all nations, reflecting the global scope of God's salvation through the servant.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 42 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42:1, what has God placed upon His servant?
questions.correctAnswer: His spirit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:1 states that God has put His spirit upon His servant, indicating divine empowerment. This is consistent with Luke 4:18 where Jesus is anointed by the Spirit for mission, Acts 10:38 describing Jesus being anointed with the Holy Spirit, and John 3:34 confirming God gives the Spirit without measure.

questions.question: What is a key characteristic of the servant’s manner of judgment described in Isaiah 42:2?
options: He shall not cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street
He shall loudly proclaim justice in the city gates
He shall command armies with a loud voice
He shall judge with a harsh and loud rebuke
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:2 emphasizes the servant’s gentle, quiet approach to judgment. This humility aligns with Jesus’ description as a gentle shepherd in Matthew 11:29, and the meekness emphasized in 2 Corinthians 10:1 and Philippians 2:5-8.

questions.question: What does the servant not do to a bruised reed or smoking flax according to Isaiah 42:3?
options: He shall not break or quench them
He will break and quench them
He will set fire to them
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not break or quench them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:3 reveals the servant’s compassion, refraining from breaking the bruised reed or quenching the smoking flax, symbolizing care for the weak. This aligns with Jesus’ care for the weak in Matthew 12:20, and God’s gentle dealings in Psalm 147:3 and 2 Corinthians 12:9.

questions.question: What is the servant's mission concerning the blind and prisoners according to Isaiah 42:7?
options: To open blind eyes and bring out prisoners from darkness
To judge the blind and imprison the captives
To ignore the prisoners and blind
To condemn the blind and the prisoners
questions.correctAnswer: To open blind eyes and bring out prisoners from darkness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:7 outlines the servant’s redemptive mission to bring light to the blind and freedom to prisoners. This mission is fulfilled in Christ (John 9:39, Luke 4:18, 2 Corinthians 3:16, Acts 26:18) who brings spiritual sight and liberty.

questions.question: In Isaiah 42:8, what does the LORD declare about His glory and praise?
options: He will not give His glory to another nor His praise to graven images
He will share His glory with kings
He will give His praise to prophets
He will distribute His glory among nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will not give His glory to another nor His praise to graven images
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:8 asserts God’s exclusive right to glory and worship, rejecting idolatry. This is consistent with Exodus 20:5, Deuteronomy 5:9, Psalm 115:4-8, and 1 Corinthians 10:14 which condemn idolatry and affirm God's unique glory.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 42:9 say about God's declarations of new things?
options: He declares new things before they spring forth
He only speaks of past events
He hides the future from His people
questions.correctAnswer: He declares new things before they spring forth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:9 emphasizes God’s prophetic knowledge and sovereignty over history, declaring new things before they happen. This is echoed in Isaiah 46:10, Revelation 1:1, Amos 3:7, and John 13:19 demonstrating God’s foreknowledge and revelation.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42:13, how is the LORD described when going forth to battle?
options: As a mighty man stirring up jealousy like a man of war
questions.correctAnswer: As a mighty man stirring up jealousy like a man of war
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:13 portrays the LORD as a warrior who goes forth in strength and zeal to prevail over enemies. This warrior motif is echoed in Exodus 15:3, Psalm 24:8, Revelation 19:11, and Joel 3:16 where God is depicted as a conquering warrior.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 42:16 say God will do for the blind?
options: Bring them by unknown ways, lead them in paths they have not known
questions.correctAnswer: Bring them by unknown ways, lead them in paths they have not known
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:16 describes God’s guidance for the blind through unfamiliar paths, turning darkness into light. This aligns with Psalm 119:105, John 8:12, John 9:25-39, and 2 Corinthians 4:6 where God illuminates the spiritually blind.

questions.question: What consequence is described in Isaiah 42:17 for those trusting in graven images?
options: They shall be turned back and greatly ashamed
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be turned back and greatly ashamed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:17 warns that those who trust in idols will be ashamed and turned back, consistent with the Old Testament rejection of idolatry (Psalm 115:4-8, Jeremiah 10:14, 1 Corinthians 10:14, Romans 1:22-23).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 42:21 describe the LORD's attitude toward righteousness and the law?
options: The LORD is well pleased for His righteousness' sake and will magnify the law
The LORD is indifferent to righteousness
The LORD hides the law from the people
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is well pleased for His righteousness' sake and will magnify the law
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:21 shows God’s delight in righteousness and His intention to exalt His law. This corresponds with Psalm 1:2, Psalm 19:7-9, Matthew 5:17-18, and Romans 3:31 affirming God's law as holy and righteous.

questions.question: In Isaiah 42:24, who is identified as the one who allowed Jacob and Israel to be given as spoil to robbers?
options: The LORD, against whom they have sinned
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD, against whom they have sinned
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:24 states God permitted Israel’s captivity because of their sin, reflecting divine judgment for disobedience (Deuteronomy 28:15-68, Psalm 78:42-43, Jeremiah 25:8-11, Romans 1:18-20).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42:6, for what purposes has the LORD called His servant?
options: For a covenant of the people and a light of the Gentiles
To bring destruction upon the earth
questions.correctAnswer: For a covenant of the people and a light of the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:6 reveals the servant’s role as God’s covenant representative and light to the Gentiles, echoing promises in Genesis 12:3, Isaiah 49:6, Acts 13:47, and Luke 2:32 where the Messiah brings salvation to all nations.

questions.question: What is the servant’s attitude toward discouragement as described in Isaiah 42:4?
options: He shall not fail nor be discouraged until judgment is established
He will be angry and frustrated
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not fail nor be discouraged until judgment is established
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:4 teaches the servant’s perseverance in establishing justice without failing or losing heart, mirroring Christ’s steadfast mission in Hebrews 12:2, Philippians 3:14, 2 Timothy 4:7, and James 1:12.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 42:18 call the deaf and blind to do?
options: Hear and look that they may see
Ignore the word of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Hear and look that they may see
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:18 urges spiritual awakening—calling those who are deaf and blind to hear and see. This theme is consistent with Ezekiel 12:2, Matthew 13:15, John 9:39-41, and Romans 11:8, where God calls His people to spiritual perception.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 42:25, what was poured out upon Israel because of their disobedience?
options: The fury of God's anger and strength of battle
questions.correctAnswer: The fury of God's anger and strength of battle
questions.explanation: Isaiah 42:25 explains the divine judgment poured out due to Israel’s sin, consistent with the Old Testament theme of punishment for disobedience in Leviticus 26:25, 2 Chronicles 36:15-16, Jeremiah 25:9, and Romans 1:18.
